Play details
The widdow. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1652. Date first performed: 1616?
Based on The Widdow (1652) Wing J1015

encodingDesc.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Francisco Martino Philippa Violetta Brandino Ricardo Atta. More than one character speaking at once Valeria Servellio. Ser. Attilio Officer. Rich. 1 suter. 2 suter. Occulto. Silvio Ansoldo Latrocinio Stratio Fiducio Prologue Epilogue

langUsage.p: l The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

body.stage: Enter Seignior Martino an old Justices Clerk) and Francisco

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Martino?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Seignior Francisco? you are the luckiest Gentleman to meet
Or see first in a morning: I never saw you yet
But I was sure of money within less than half an hour.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I bring you the same luck still.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What you do not?
I hope Sir you are not come for another Warrant?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Yes faith, for another Warrant.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why there is my dream come out then. I never dreamed of a buttock but I was sure to have money for a Warrant. It is the luckiest part of all the body to me: let every man speak as he finds. Now your Usurer is of opinion, that to dream of the Devil is your wealthier dream; and I think if a man dream of that part that brings many to the Devil, it is as good; and has all one smatch indeed; for if one be the flesh, the other is the broth: So it is in all his members if we mark it; if Gluttony be the meat, Lechery is the Porridge, they are both boiled together, and we Clerks will have our modicum too, though it conclude in the two penny chop: Why Sir, Seignior Francisco.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: It was her voice sure,
Or my soul takes delight to think it was,
And makes a sound like hers.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: It is the prettiest contrived building, this:
What Poesy is that I prithee?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Which Sir, that
Under the great brass Squirt?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Aye that Sir, that

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: From fire, from water, and all things amiss,
Deliver the house of an honest Justice?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: There is like to be a good house kept then, when fire and water is forbidden to come into the Kitchen.
Not yet a sight of her ? this hour is unfortunate.
And what is that yonder prithee? O loves famine,
There is no affliction like thee. Aye , I hear you Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You are quicker eared than I then: you hear me
Before I heard myself .

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: A gift in friendship
Some call it an instinct.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It may be
The other is the sweeter phrase though; Look you Sir,
Mine own wit this, and it is as true as turtle;
A Goosequill and a Clerk, a Constable and a Lantern,
Brings many a Bawd from Coach to Cart, and many a Thief to one turn.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: That one turn helped you well.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: it has helped me to money indeed for many a Warrant. I am 40. dollars the better for that one turn; if it would come off quicker it were never a whit the worse for me. But indeed when Thieves are taken, and break away twice or thrice one after another , there is my gains; then goes out more Warrants to fetch them again : one fine nimble villain, may be worth a man ten dollars in and out of that fashion; I love such a one with my heart, aye , and will help him to scape too , if I can; hear you me that : I will have him in at all times at a months warning: nay, say I let him run like a Summer Nag all the Vacation: See you these blanks, I will send him but one of these bridles, and bring him in at Michaelmas with a vengeance: nothing kills my heart, but when one of them dies Sir; then there is no hope of more money: I had rather lose at all times two of my best kindred, than an excellent Thief: for he is a Gentleman I am more beholding to

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You betray your mystery too much Sir. Yet no comfort?
It is but her sight that I waste precious time for ,
For more I cannot hope for , she is so strict,
Yet that I cannot have.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am ready now Seignior.
Here are blank Warrants of all dispositions, give me but the name and nature of your Malefactor, and I will bestow him according to his merits.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: This only is the excuse that bears me out,
And keeps off impudence and suspicion
From my too frequent coming : what name now
Shall I think on , and not to wrong the house?
This Coxcomb will be prating. ~~ One Astilio,
His offence wilful murder.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Wilful murder? o I love a life to have such a fellow come under my fingers; like a beggar that is long a-taking leave of a fat louse, I am loath to part with him, I must look upon him over and over first; are you wilful? in faith, I will be as wilful as you then.

body.stage: Philippa and Violetta at a Window.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Martino?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Mistress?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Make haste your Master is going.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am but about a wilful murder forsooth, I will dispatch that presently.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Good morrow Sir: o that I durst say more.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: It is gone again , since; such are all lifes pleasures,
No sooner known, but lost; he that enjoys them
The length of life, has but a longer dream,
He wakes to this in the end, and sees all nothing.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: He cannot see me now; I will mark him better
Before I be too rash: sweetly composed he is;
Now as he stands, he is worth a woman's love,
That loves only for shape, as most of us do :
But I must have him wise, as well as proper,
He comes not in my Books else, and indeed
I have thought upon a course to try his wit: Violetta

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Yonder is the Gentleman again .

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: O sweet Mistress
Pray give me leave to see him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay take heed,
Open not the window if you love me.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: No , I have the view of whole body here, Mistress,
At this pore little slit, o enough, enough,
In troth it is a fine outside.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I see that .

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Has curled his hair most judiciously well.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Aye there is thy love, now, it begins in barbarism: she buys a Goose with feathers, that loves a Gentleman for his hair; she may be cozened to her face Wench. Away: he takes his leave. Reach me that letter hither, quick, quick Wench.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nay look upon it , and spare not: everyone cannot get that kind of Warrant from me Seignior. Do you see this prick in the bottom, it betokens power and speed, it is a privy mark, that runs betwixt the Constables and my Master. Those that cannot read, when they see this, know it is for Lechery or Murder, and this being away, the Warrant comes gelded, and insufficient.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I thank you Sir,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Look you; all these are Nihils,
They want the punction.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Yes, I see they do Sir,
There is for thy pains, mine must go unrewarded,
The better love, the worse by fate regarded.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Well, go thy ways, for the sweetest Customer that ever Penman was blessed with all: now will he come for another tomorrow again ; if he hold on this course, he will leave never a knave in the town within this twelve month: no matter, I shall be rich enough by that time.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Martino?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Say you forsooth.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What paper is that the Gentleman let fall there?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Paper? It is the Warrant I hope, if it be I will hide it, and make him pay for it again . No Pox: it is not so happy.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What is it Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It is nothing but a letter forsooth.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Is that nothing?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nothing, in respect of a Warrant Mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: A letter? why it has been many a man's undoing Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: So has a Warrant, if you go to that Mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Read but the superscription; and away with it :
Alas it may concern the Gentleman nearly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why Mistress, this letter is at home already.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: At home, how mean your Sir?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You shall hear Mistress. To the deservingest of all her Sex, and most worthy of his best respect and love, Mistress. Philippa Brandino.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How Sir, to me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: To you Mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Run, as thou lovest my honour, and thy life,
Call him again , I will not endure this injury.
But stay, stay now I think on it , it is my credit,
I will have your Masters Counsel: ah base fellow
To leave his loose lines thus; it is even as much
As a poor honest Gentlewoman's undoing,
Had I not a grave wise man to my Husband:
And thou a vigilant varlet to admit
Thou carest not whom

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas it is my office Mistress.
You know you have a Kirtle every year,
And it is within two months of the time now,
sp.p: The velvets coming over: pray be milder; a man that has a place must take money of any body: please you to throw me down but half a dollar, and I will make you a warrant for him now, that is all I care for him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Well, look you be clear now from this foul conspiracy
Against mine honour; or your Masters love to you
That makes you flout, shall not maintain you here;
It shall not: trust to it ~~

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: This is strange to me now:
Dare she do this, and but eight weeks to New years tide?
sp.p: A man that had his blood as hot as hers now, would fit her with French Velvet: I will go near it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: If this be a wrong to modest reputation
Be you the censurer Sir, that are the Master
Both of your fame and mine.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Seignior Francisco?
I will make him fly the land.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That will be hard Sir;
I think he be not so well feathered Master,
He has spent the best part of his patrimony.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hark of his bold confederate.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: There thou art bitter;
And I must chide thee now.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What should I think Sir?
He comes to your man for Warrants.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: There it goes then;
Come hither knave: Comes he to you for Warrants?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why, what of that Sir?
You know I give no Warrants to make Cuckolds.
That comes by fortune, and by nature Sir.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: True, that comes by fortune, and by nature; Wife
Why dost thou wrong this man?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He needs no Warrant Master, that goes about such business, a Cuckold maker carries always his warrant about him.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: La: has he answered well now? to the full?
What cause hast thou to abuse him?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hear me out I pray:
Through his admittance, he has had opportunity
To come into the house, and court me boldly.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Sirrah, you are foul again methinks .

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Who I Sir?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: You gave this man admittance into the house.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That is true Sir, you never gave me any order yet
To write my Warrants in the street.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Why sure thou takest delight to wrong this fellow, Wife
Hah, cause I love him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Pray see the fruits: see what has left behind here:
Be angry where you should be: there is few Wives
Would do as I do

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Nay I will say that for thee
I never found thee but honest.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: She is a beast
That ever was found otherways.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Read Martino,
Mine eyes are sore already, and such business
Would put them out quite

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Fair, dear and incomparable Mistress, ~~

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: O ! every letter draws a tooth methinks .

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And it leads mine to watering

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Here is no villainy?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My love being so violent, and the opportunity so precious in your husbands absence tonight , who as I understand takes a journey this morning.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: O plot of villainy.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Am I honest think you Sir?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Exactly honest, perfectly improved: on , on Martino.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I will make bold dear Mistress, though your chastity has given me many a repulse, to wait the sweet blessings of this long desired opportunity, at the back gate, between nine and ten this night.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: I feel this Inns of Court man in my Temples.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Where if your affection be pleased to receive me, you receive the faithfullest that ever vowed service to woman ~~ Francisco.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: I will make Francisco smart for it .

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Show him the letter, let him know, you know him;
That will torment him: all your other courses
Are nothing Sir to that : that breaks his heart.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: The strings shall not hold long then: Come Martino.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Now if Francisco have any wit at all,
He comes at night; if not, he never shall.

body.stage: Enter Francisco and Ricardo and Attilio

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Nay mark, mark it Francisco: It was the naturallest courtesy that ever was ordained; A young Gentleman being spent, to have a rich Widow set him up again : to see how fortune has provided for all mortalities ruins; your College for your old standing Scholar, your Hospital for your lame creeping Soldier, your Bawd for your mangled Roarer, your open house for your Beggar, and your Widow for your Gentleman: ha Francisco?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Aye Sir, you may be merry: you are in hope of a rich Widow.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: And why shouldest not thou be in hope of another, if there were any spirit in thee, thou art as likely a fellow as any is in the company. I will be hanged now if I do not hit the true cause of thy sadness; and confess truly in faith; thou hast some land unsold yet, I hold my life.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Marry I hope so Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: A Pox on it , have I found it? 'slight away with it with all speed man. I was never merry at heart while I had a foot: why man, Fortune never minds us , till we are left alone to ourselves : for what need she take care for them, that do nothing but take care for themselves? why, dost think if I had kept my lands still, I should ever have looked after a rich Widow? alas, I should have married some poor young Maid, got five and twenty children, and undone myself .

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: I protest Sir, I should not have the face though, to come to a rich Widow with nothing

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Why, art thou so simple, as thou makest thyself ? dost think in faith I come to a rich Widow with nothing?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I mean with state not answerable to hers.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Why there is the fortune, man, that I talked on ;
She knows all this, and yet I am welcome to her .

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Aye , that is strange Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Nay more to pierce thy hard heart, and make thee sell thy land if thou hast any grace: she has amongst others two substantial Suitors,
sp.l: One, in good time be it spoke, I owe much money to ,
She knows this too, and yet I am welcome to her ,
Nor dares the unconscionable Rascal trouble me;
She has told him thus, those that profess love to her
Shall have the liberty to come and go ,
Or else get him gone first; she knows not yet
Where fortune may bestow her , she is her gift,
Therefore to all will show a kind respect.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why this is like a woman: I have no luck in it .

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: And as at a Sheriffs table, O blessed custom,
A poor indebted Gentleman may dine,
Feed well, and without fear, and depart so ,
So to her lips, fearless I come and go ?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You may well boast, you are much the happier man Sir

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: So you would be, if you would sell your land Sir

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I have heard the circumstance of your sweet fortunes:
prithee give ear to my unlucky tale now.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: That is an ill hearing; but come on for once Sir.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I never yet loved but one Woman.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Right, I begun so too; but I have loved a thousand since.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Pray hear me Sir; but this is a man's wife.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: So has five hundred of my thousand been.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Nay see if you will regard me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: No ? you see I do ,
I bring you an example in for everything .

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: This man's wife

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: So you said.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Seems very strict

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Ha, hum.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Do you laugh at that ?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Seems very strict you said,
I hear you man, in faith you are so jealous still.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: But why should that make you laugh?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Because she seems so : you are such another ~~

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Nay Sir, I think she is.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: You cannot tell then.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I dare not ask the question I protest
For fear of a repulse, which yet not having,
My mind is the quieter, and I live in hope still.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Ha, hum: this it is to be a landed man. Come, I perceive
I must show you a little of my fortune, and instruct you:
Not ask the question?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Methought still she frowned Sir?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Why that is the cause fool, that she looked so scurvily.
Come, come, make me your woman, you will never it else,
I will show you her condition presently.
sp.p: I perceive you must begin like a young Vaulter, and get up at horsetail, before you get into the saddle; have you the boldness to utter your mind to me now, being but in hose and doublet? I think if I should put on a Farthingale, thou wouldst never have the heart to it .

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Perhaps I should not then for laughing at you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: In the mean time I fear I shall laugh at thee without one.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Nay you must think friend, I dare speak to a woman.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: You shall pardon me for that friend; I will not think it, till I see it .

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why you shall then: I shall be glad to learn too,
Of one so deep as you are.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: So you may Sir; Now it is my best course to look mildly, I shall put him out at first else.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: A word, sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: With me Sir? say your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O Ricardo
Thou art too good to be a woman long.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Do not find fault with this, for fear I prove
Too scornful, be content when you are well used.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You say well Sir. Lady I have loved you long.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: It is a good hearing Sir. If he be not out now I will be hanged.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You play a scornful woman? I perceive Ricardo,

You have not been used to them : why I will come in at my pleasure with you: alas it is nothing for a man to talk, when a woman gives way to it : one shall seldom meet with a Lady so kind, as thou playedest her .

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Not altogether perhaps: he that draws their pictures must flatter them a little, they will look he that plays them should do it a great deal then.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Come, come I will play the woman, that I am used too,
I see you never wore shoe that pinched you yet,
All your things comes on easy.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Say you so Sir?
I will try your Ladyship in faith: Lady well met.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I do not think so Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: A scornful Gom,
And at the first dash too: my Widow never gave me such an answer, I will to you again Sir.
Fairest of creatures, I do love thee infinitely.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: There is nobody bids you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Pox on thee thou art the beastliest crossest Baggage that ever man met withal; but I will see thee hanged sweet Lady ere I be daunted with this: why thou art too awkward Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Hang thee base fellow.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Now by this light, he thinks he dost indeed,
Nay then have at your plum tree faith, I will not be foiled,
Though you seem to be careless Madam, as you have enough wherewithall to be, yet I do , must, and will love you.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sir, if you begin to be rude, I will call my woman.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: What a pestilent Quean is this? I shall have much ado with her I see that ; tell me as you are a woman Lady, what serve kisses for ? but to stop all your mouths.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Hold, hold Ricardo.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Disgrace me Widow.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Art mad, I am Francisco?

sp.speaker: Atta.
sp.l: Seignior Ricardo, up , up .

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Who is it Francisco?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Francisco quoth he ? what are you mad Sir?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: A bots on thee, thou dost not know what injury thou hast done me, I was in the fairest dream, this is your way now, and you can follow it.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: It is a strange way methinks .

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Learn you to play a woman not so scornfully then,
For I am like the Actor that you spoke on ,
I must have the part that overcomes the Lady,
I never like the Play else. ~~ Now your friendship,
But to assist a subtle trick I have thought on ,
And the rich Widow is mine within these three hours.

sp.speaker: Att. Fra.
sp.l: We should be proud of that Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: List to me then.
I will place you too, I can it handsomely
I know the house so well, to hear the conference
Twixt her and I, she is a most affable one,
Her words will give advantage, and I will urge them
To the kind proof, to catch her in a Contract,
Then shall you both step in as witnesses,
And take her in the snare.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: But do you love her ?
And then it will prosper.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: By this hand I do ,
Not for her wealth, but for her person too.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: It shall be done then.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: But stay, stay Francisco
Where shall we meet with thee some two hours hence now?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why hark you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Enough, command my life,
Get me the widow, I will get thee the wife.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O that is now with me past hope; yet I must love her ,
I would I could not it .

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yonder is the villain Master.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Francisco; I am happy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let us both draw Master. for there is nobody with him; Stay, stay Master.
Do not you draw till I be ready too,
Let us draw just both together, and keep even .

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: What if we killed him now, before he saw us ?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No , then he will hardly see to read the letter.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: That is true: good counsel marry.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Marry thus much Sir,
You may kill him lawfully, all the while he is a reading on it , as an
Anabaptist may lie with a Brothers wife all the while he is asleep.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: He turns; he looks: Come on Sir, you, Francisco
I loved your father well, but you are a villain:
He loved me well too; but you love my wife Sir,
After whom take you that ? I will not say
Your Mother played false.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: No Sir, you were not best.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: But I will say, in spite of thee, my wife is honest.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And I, my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You may, I will give you leave.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Leave, or leave not, there, she defies you Sir;
Keep your adulterous sheet to wind you in ,
Or cover your forbidden parts at least ,
For fear you want one; many a lecher may
That sins in Cambric now.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And in Lawn too Master.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Nay read, and tremble Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now shall I it Master? I see a piece of an open seam in his Shirt, shall I run him in there, for my Sword has never a point.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: No , let him foam a while.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: If your Sword be no better than mine, we shall not kill him by daylight, we had need have a Lantern.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Talk not of Lanterns, he is a sturdy Lecher,
He would make the horns fly about my ears.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I apprehend thee: admirable woman,
Which to love best I know not; thy wit, or beauty.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Now Sir, have you well viewed your bastard there,
Got of your lustful brain? God give you joy on it .

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I thank you Sir, although you speak in jest,
I must confess, I sent your wife this letter,
And often courted her , tempted, and urged her .

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Did you so Sir?
Then first before I kill thee, I forewarn thee my house.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And I before I kill thee, forewarn thee my office; die tomorrow next, thou never gettest Warrant of me more, for love, or money.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Remember but again , from whence I came Sir,
And then I know you cannot think amiss of me.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: How is this?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Pray hear him: it may grow to a peace:
For Master. though we have carried the business nobly, we are not altogether so valiant as we should be.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Peace, thou sayst true in that : what is it you would say Sir?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Was not my Father, (quietness be with him)
And you sworn Brothers?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Why Right: that is it urges me.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: And could you have a thought that I could wrong you,
As far as the deed goes?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: You took the course Sir.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: To make you happy, if you rightly weighed it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Troth I will put up at all adventures Master.
It comes off very fair yet.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You in years
Married a young Maid: what does the world judge think you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: B'r'lady Master. knavishly enough I warrant you,
I should do so myself .

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Now to damp slander,
And all her envious and suspicious brood,
I made this friendly trial of her constancy,
Being Son to him you loved; that now confirmed
I might advance my Sword against the world
In her most fair defence, which joys my spirit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O Master. let me weep while you embrace him.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Francisco: is thy fathers soul in thee?
Lives he here still? what, will he show himself
In his male seed to me? give me thy hand,
Methinks it feels now like thy fathers to me,
prithee forgive me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And me too , prithee.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Come to my house, thy father never missed it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Fetch now as many Warrants as you please Sir,
And welcome too.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: To see how soon man's goodness
May be abused.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: But now I know thy intent
Welcome to all that I have.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sir, I take it:
A gift so given, hang him that would forsake it.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Martino I applaud my fortune, and thy Counsel.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You never have ill fortune when you follow it.
Here was things carried now, in the true nature of a quiet Duello;
A great strife ended, without the rough Soldier, or the ~~
And now you may take your journey.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Thou art my glee Martino.

body.stage: Enter Valeria the Widow and a Servant.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Servellio.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Mistress.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: If that fellow come again ,
Answer him without me: I will not speak with him.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: He in the Nutmeg coloured band forsooth.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Aye, that spiced coxcomb Sir: Never may I marry again
If his right worshipful idolatrous face
Be not most fearfully painted, painted, so hope comfort me,
I might perceive it peel in many places,
And under his eye, lay a betraying foulness,
As Maids sweep dust of the house, all to one corner,
It showed me enough there, prodigious pride
That cannot but fall scornfully. I am a woman,
Yet I praise heaven, I never had the ambition
To go about to mend a better Workman,
She ever shames herself, in the end, that does it.
He that likes me not now, as heaven made me,
I will never hazard hell to do him a pleasure;
Nor lie every night like a Woodcock in past
To please some gaudy Goose in the morning:
A wise man likes that best, that is itself,,
Not that which only seems, though it look fairer;
Heaven send me one that loves me, and I am happy,
Of whom I will make great trial ere I have him,
Though I speak all men fair, and promise sweetly,
I learn that of my Suitors, it is their own,
Therefore injustice it were to keep it from them .

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: And so as I said sweet Widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Do you begin where you left Sir?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: I always desire when I come to a Window, to begin in the middle of a sentence, for I presume, she has a bad memory of a woman that cannot remember what goes before.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Stay, stay Sir, let me look upon you well,
Are not you painted too?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: How, painted, Widow?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not painted Widow, I do not use it trust me Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: That makes me love thee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I mean painted Gentleman,
Or if you please to give him a greater style Sir;
Blame me not Sir, it is a dangerous age I tell you,
Poor simple dealing women had need look about them.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: But is there such a fellow in the world, Widow,
As you are pleased to talk on ?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nay, here lately Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Here? a Pox, I think I smell him, it is Vermilion sure, ha : oil of Ben, do but show him me Widow, and let me never hope for comfort, if I do not immediately geld him, and grind his face upon one of the stones.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Suffices you have, expressed me your love and valour, and manly hate against that unmanly pride: but Sir, I will save you that labour, he never comes within my door again .

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: I will love your door the better while I know it, Widow; a pair of such Brothers were fitter for Posts without door indeed, to make a show at a new chosen Magistrates, than to be used in a Woman's Chamber: No , sweet Widow, having me, you have, the truth of a man, all that you see of me, is full mine own, and what you see, or not see, shall be yours: I ever hated to be beholding to art , or to borrow anything but money.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: True, and that you never use to pay again .

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: What matter is it ? if you be pleased to it
For me, I hold it as good.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O, soft you Sir I pray.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Why in faith you may and you will .

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I know that Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Troth, and I would have my will then if I were as you.
There is few women else but has.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But since I cannot have it in all Seignior, I care not to have it in anything.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Why you may have it in all, if you will Widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Pish, I would have one that loves me for myself Sir,
Not for my wealth: and that I cannot have.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: What say you to him that does the thing you wish for ?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why here is my hand, I will marry none but him then.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Your hand, and faith.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My hand, and faith.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: It is I then.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I shall be glad of it trust me: shrew my heart else.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: A match.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Give you joy, sweet Widow.

sp.speaker: At.
sp.l: Joy to you both.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Nay, there is no starting now, I have you fast Widow,
You are witness Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fra. Att.
sp.l: We will be deposed on it .

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Am I betrayed to this then? then I see
It is for my wealth; a woman's wealth is her Traitor.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: It is for love chiefly, I protest sweet Widow,
I count wealth but a fiddle to make us merry.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Hence.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Why thou art mine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I do renounce it utterly.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Have I not hand and faith?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir, take your course.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: With all my heart; ten courses if you will Widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir, Sir, I am not so gamesome as you think me,
I will stand you out by law.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: By Law? O cruel merciless woman,
To talk of law, and know I have no money.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I will consume myself to the last stamp,
Before thou gettest me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: 'Slife, I will be as wilful then too: I will rob all the Carriers in Christendom, but I will have thee, and find my Lawyers money:
sp.l: I scorn to get thee under forma pauperis
I have too proud a heart, and love thee better.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: As for you Gentlemen, I will take course against you;
You came into my house without my leave;
Your practices are cunning, and deceitful;
I know you not, and I hope law will right me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: It is sufficient that your husband knows them ,
It is not your business to know every man,
An honest wife contents herself, with one.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You know what you shall trust to , pray depart Sir,
And take your rude confederates along with you,
Or I will send for those shall force your absence:
I am glad I found your purpose out so soon.
How quickly may poor women be undone.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Lose thee? by this hand I will see fifteen Counsellors first, though, I undo a hundred poor men for them , and I will make them yawl one another deaf, but I will have thee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Me?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Thee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Aye, fret thy heart out.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Were I he now
I would see thee starve for man before I had thee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Pray counsel him to that Sir, and I will pay you well.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Pay me? pay your next husband.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Do not scorn it gallant: a worse woman than I,
Has paid a better man than you.
Why how now sweet Widow?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O kind Gentlemen,
I am so abused here.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: Abused?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What will you do Sirs? put up your weapons.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: Nay, they are not so easily drawn, that I must tell you
you, mine has not been out this three years; marry in your cause Widow, it would not be long a-drawing. Abused? by whom Widow?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nay, by a beggar.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: A beggar? I will have him whipped then, and sent to the house of Correction.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ricardo Sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: Ricardo? nay by'th'mass he is a Gentleman beggar, he will be hanged before he be whipped. Why you will give me leave to clap him up I hope?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It is too good for him; that is the thing he would have,
He would be clapped up whether I would or no methinks;
Placed two of his companions privately,
Unknown to me, on purpose to entrap me
In my kind answers, and at last stole from me,
That which I fear will put me to some trouble,
A kind of verbal courtesy, which his witnesses
And he forsooth call by the name of contract.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: O politic villain,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But I am resolved Gentlemen,
If the whole power of my estate can cast him,
He never shall obtain me.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: Hold you there Widow,
Well fare your heart for that in faith.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: Stay, stay, stay,
You broke no gold between you?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: We broke nothing Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: Nor drunk to one another ?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not a drop Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: You are sure of this you speak?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Most certain Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: Be of good comfort wench, I will undertake then
At mine own charge to overthrow him for thee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O do but that Sir, and you bind me to you,
Here shall I try your goodness. I am but a woman,
And alas, ignorant in Law businesses,
I will bear the charge most willingly.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: Not a penny,
Thy love will reward me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And where love must be,
It is all but one purse now I think on it .

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: All comes to one, sweet Widow.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: Are you so forward?

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: I know his mates Attilio and Francisco,
I will get out process and and attach them all,
We will begin first with them.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I like that , strangely.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: I have a daughter run away I thank her ,
I will be a scourge to all youth for her sake:
Some of them has got her up .

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Your daughter? what Sir? Martia.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: Aye, a shake wed her ,
I would have married her to a wealthy Gentleman,
No older than myself , she was like to be shrewdly hurt Widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It was too happy for her .

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: I am of thy mind.
Farewell sweet Widow, I will about this strait,
I will have them all three put into one Writ,
And so save charges.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How I love your providence.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: Is my Nose board? I will cross ye both for this,
Although it cost me as much of the other side,
I have enough, and I will have my humour.
I may get out of her , what may undo her too;
Hark you sweet Widow, you must now take heed,
You be of a sure ground, he will overthrow your else.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Marry fair hope forbid.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.p: That will he: marry let me see, let me see: pray how far past it between you and Ricardo?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Farther Sir
Than I would now it had, but I hope well yet.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: Pray let me hear it: I have a shrewd guess of the Law.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Faith Sir, I rashly gave my hand and faith
To marry none but him.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: Indeed?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Aye, trust me Sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: I am very glad of it , I am another witness,
And he shall have you now.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What said you Sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: He shall not want money in an honest cause Widow,
I know I have enough, and I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Are all the world betrayers.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: Pish, pish, Widow.
You have, borne me in hand this three months, and now fobbed me
I have known the time when I could please a woman,
I will not be laughed at now; when I am crossed, I am a Tiger;
I have enough, and I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This only shows your malice to me Sir,
The world knows you have small reason to help him,
So much in your debt already.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: Therefore I do it ,
I have no way but that to help myself ;
Though I lose you, I will not lose all Widow;
He marrying you, as I will follow it for him,
I will make you pay his debts, or lie without him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I looked for this from you.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: I have not deceived you then:
Fret, vex, and chafe, I am obstinate where I take.
I will seek him out, and cheer him up , against her ,
I have no charge at all, no child of mine own,
But two I got once of a scouring woman,
And they are both well provided for , they are in the Hospital:
I have ten thousand pound to bury me, and I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: A man must have a time to serve his pleasure,
As well as his dear Friend, I am forced to steal from them ,
To get this night of sport for mine own use:
What says her amiable witty letter here?
Twixt nine and ten, now it is twixt six and seven,
As fit as can be; he that follows Lechery,
Leaves all at six and seven, and so do I methinks :
Sun sets at eight, it is above an hour high yet,
Some fifteen mile have I before I reach her ,
But I have an excellent horse; and a good gallop,
Helps man as much as a provoking Banquet.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: Here is one of them , begin with him first Officers.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: By virtue of this writ we attach your body Sir.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: My body? 'Slife, for what?

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: Hold him fast Officers.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: The least of us can do it , now his Sword is off Sir,
We have a trick of hanging upon Gentlemen,
We never lose a man.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O treacherous fortune,
Why what is the cause?

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: The widows business Sir,
I hope you know me?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: For a busy Coxcomb,
This fifteen year, I take it.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: O you are mad Sir,
Simple though you make me, I stand for the Widow.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: She is simply stood for then: what is this to me Sir,
Or she, or you, or any of these flesh hooks?

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: you are like to find good bail before you leave us ,
Or lie till the Suit is tried.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O my loves misery.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: I am put in trust to follow it, and I will it with all severity;
Build upon that Sir.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: How I would curse myself .

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Look, here is Francisco
Will you believe me, now you see his qualities?

sp.speaker: Attilio.
sp.l: It is strange to me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I tell you it is his fashion,
He never stole away in his life from me,
But still I found him in such scurvy Company;
A pox on thee Francisco wilt never leave thy old
Tricks, are these lousy Companions for thee?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Pish, pish, pish.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: Here they be all three now: apprehend them Officers.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: What is this?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I gave you warning enough to make away,
I am in for the Widows business, so are you now.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: What, all three in a noose? this is like a Widows business indeed.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: She has catched you Gentlemen, as you catched her ,
The Widow means now, to begin with you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: I thank her heartily, she has taught me wit: for had I been any but an ass, I should have begun with her indeed: by this light, the widow is a notable Housewife, she bestirs herself, I have a greater mind to her now than ever I had: I cannot go to prison for one I love better I protest, that is one good comfort,
sp.l: And what are you I pray Sir, for a Coxcomb?

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: It seems you know me by your anger Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I have a near guess at you Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: Guess what you please Sir,
I am he ordained to trounce you, and indeed
I am the man must carry her .

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Aye, to me.
But I will swear she is a beast, if she carry thee.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: Come, where is your Bail Sir, quickly, or away.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Sir, I am held wrongfully, my Bail is taken already.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: Where is it Sir, where?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Here they be both: pox on you, they were taken before I had need of them , if you be honest Officers let us Bail one another, for by this hand, I do not know who will else: ~~ Gods light is he come too? I am in for midnight then, I shall never find the way out again : my debts, my debts:
sp.l: I am like to die in the hole now.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: We have him fast old Seignior, and his Consorts,
Now you may lay action on action on him.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: That may I Sir, in faith.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: And I would not spare him Sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: Know you me Officers?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: Your bounteous worship Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I know the rascal so well, I dare not look upon him.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: Upon my worth deliver me that Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Which Gentleman?

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: Not you Sir, you are too hasty;
No , nor you neither Sir: pray stay your time.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: There is all but I now, and I dare not think he means me.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: Deliver me Ricardo,

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: O sure he lies,
Or else I do not hear well.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: Seignior Ricardo

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Well, what is the matter? you may go , who lets you?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: It is his worships pleasure Sir to Bail you.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Bail me?

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: I will , I Sir, look in my face man,
Thou hast a good cause, thou wilt pay me when thou art able?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Aye, every penny, as I am a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: no matter if thou dost not, then, I will make thee,
And that is as good at all times.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: But I pray Sir,
You go against the Hair there.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: Against the Widow you mean Sir,
Why it is my purpose truly, and against you too,
I saw your politic Combination,
I was thrust out between you: here stands one
Shall do as much for you, and he stands rightest,
His cause is strong and fair, nor shall he want
Money, or means, or friends, but he shall have her ,
I have enough, and I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: Hang thee; I have a purse as good as thine.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I think they are much alike, they are rich knaves both.
'Sheart, and I take your railing at my Patron Sir,
I will cramp your joints.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: Let him alone sweet honey,
I thank thee for thy love though.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: This is wonderful.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: O Ricardo
It is seven, struck in my pocket: I lose time now.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: What sayst Francisco?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I have mighty business,
That I never thought on : get me Bailed, I am spoiled else.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Why you know, it is such a strange miraculous courtesy,
I dare not be too forward, to ask more of him,
For fear he repent this, and turn me in again .

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Do somewhat if you love me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I will make trial in faith
May it please you Sir: ~~ 'Slife if I should spoil all now?

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: What sayst Ricardo?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Only a thing by the way Sir,
Use your own pleasure.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: That I like well from thee.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: It were good, if those two Gentlemen were Bailed too,
They are both my witnesses.

sp.speaker: 2 Suiter.
sp.l: they are well, they are well;
If they were Bailed, we know not where to find them ,
Let them go to prison, they will be forthcoming the better,
I have enough, and I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I knew there was no more good to be done upon him,
It is well I have this, heaven knows I never looked for it .

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: What plaguey luck had I to be ensnared thus?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: O, patience.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Pox on your comfortable ignorance.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Martino, we ride slow.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But we ride sure Sir,
Your hasty riders often come short home Master.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: God bless this fair company.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Here he is again too,
I am both shamed, and crossed.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Martino Seest thou who is yonder,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: We ride slow, I will be sworn now Master.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Francisco. How now art thou got before me?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Yes, thank my fortune, I am got before you.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: What no ? in hold?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Aye, on my troth poor Gentleman,
Your worship Sir, may do a good deed to Bail him.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Why do not you it then?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: La you Sir now, my Master. he has that honesty
He is loath to take a good deed from you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I will tell you why I cannot, else I would Sir.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Luck I beseech thee,
If he should be wrought to Bail me now, to go to
His wife, it were happiness beyond expression.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: A matter but of controversy.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: That is all, trust me Sir.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Francisco shall never lie for it ; he is my friend,
And I will Bail him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He is your secret friend Master.
Think upon that .

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Give him his liberty Officers,
Upon my peril, he shall be forthcoming .

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: How I am bound to you?

sp.speaker: 1 Suiter.
sp.l: Know you whom you cross Sir?
It is at your Sisters suit, be well advised Sir,

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: How, at my Sisters suit? take him again then.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why Sir, do you refuse me?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: I will not hear thee.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: This is unkindly done sir.

sp.speaker: 1 suter.
sp.l: It is wisely done sir.

sp.speaker: 2 suter.
sp.l: Well shot, foul malice.

sp.speaker: 1 suter.
sp.l: Flattery stinks worse sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: You will never leave till I make you stink as bad sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: O Martino have I this for my late kindness?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas poor Gentleman, dost complain to me?
Thou shalt not fare the worse for it : Hark you Master,
Your sisters suit said you?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Aye sir, my wife's sister.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And shall that daunt you Master? think again ,
Why were it your mothers suit; your mothers suit,
Mark what I say, the dearest suit of all suits,
You are bound in conscience sir to bail this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Martino Yea, am I so , how provest thou that

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Have you forgot so soon, what he did lately?
Has he not tried your wife to your hand master?
To cut the throat of slander and suspicion;
And can you do too much for such a man?
Shall it be said, I serve an ingrateful master?

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Never Martino; I will bail him now,
If it were at my wives suit.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: It is like to be so .

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And I his friend, to follow your example Master.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Precious Martino.

sp.speaker: 1 suter.
sp.l: You have done wondrous well sir.
Your sister shall give you thanks.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: This makes him mad sir.

sp.speaker: 2 suter.
sp.l: We will follow it now to the proof.

sp.speaker: 1 suter.
sp.l: Follow your humour out,
The widow shall find friends.

sp.speaker: 2 suter.
sp.l: And so shall he sir,
Money and means.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Hear you me that old huddle.

sp.speaker: 2 suter.
sp.l: Mind him not, follow me and I will supply thee,
Thou shalt give all thy Lawyers double fees,
I have buried money enough to bury me,
And I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Fare thee well once again my dear Francisco,
I prithee use my house.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: It is my purpose sir.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Nay you must it then; though I am old, I am free.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And when you want a warrant, come to me.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: That will be shortly now, within this few hours.
This fell out strangely happy. Now to horse,
I shall be knighted; but an hour or two
Never breaks square in love; he comes in time
That comes at all; absence is all loves crime.

body.stage: Enter Occulto, Silvio and two or three other Thieves.

sp.speaker: Occulto.
sp.l: Come come, let us watch the event on yonder hill;
If he need help, we can relieve him suddenly.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Aye, and with safety too, the hill being watched Sir.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Have you the Blew cotes and the Beards?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: they are here Sir.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Come, come away then, a fine Cock shoot evening.

body.stage: Enter Latrocinio the chief Thief, and Ansoldo

sp.l: Cuck before, and Cuck behind, etc.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Troth you are the merriest, and delightfullest company Sir,
That ever Traveller was blessed withal,
I praise my fortune that I overtook you Sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Pish, I have a hundred of them .

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: And believe me Sir,
I am infinitely taken with such things.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I see there is music in you, you kept time methought
Pretty and handsomely with your little hand there.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: It only shows desire, but troth, no skill Sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Well, while our horses walk down yonder hill Sir,
I will have another for you.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: It rids way pleasantly.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Let me see now: one confounds another sir,
You have, heard this certainly: Come my dainty Doxies.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: O, that is all the Country over sir,
There is scarce Gentlewoman, but has that pricked.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Well, here comes one I am sure you never heard then.
I keep my Horse, I keep my Whore,
I take no Rents, yet am not poor;
I traverse all the Land about,
And yet was born to never a foot:
With Partridge plump, with Woodcock fine
I do at midnight often dine;
And if my Whore be not in case,
My Hostess daughter has her place;
The Maids sit up , and watch their turns,
If I stay long the Tapster mourns;
The Cook maid has no mind to sin,
Though tempted by the Chamberlain;
But when I knock, o how they bustle,
The Ostler yawns, the Geldings jostle.
If Maid but sleep, o how they curse her!
And all this comes of, Deliver your purse sir.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: How Sir?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Few words: quickly come, deliver your purse sir.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: you are not that kind of Gentleman, I hope sir,
To sing me out of my money?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: It is most fit
Art should be rewarded: you must pay your Music sir
Wherever you come.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: But not at your own carving.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Nor am I common in it : Come, come your purse sir.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Say it should prove the undoing of a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why sir, do you look for more conscience in us , than
In Usurers? young gentleman, you have, small reason for that in faith.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: There it is , and all I have; and so truth comfort me,
All I know where to have.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Sir, that is not written
In my belief yet; search, it is a fine evening,
Your horse can take no harm: I must have more sir.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: May my hopes perish, if you have not all sir,
And more I know than your compassionate charity
Would keep from me, if you but felt my wants.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Search, and that speedily: if I take you in hand,
You will find me rough, methinks men should be ruled,
When they are so kindly spoke too, fie upon it .

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Good fortune, and my wit assist me then,
A thing I took in haste, and never thought on it :
Look sir, I have searched, here is all that I can find,
If you are so covetous, you will have all you say,
And I am content you shall, being kindly spoke too.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: A pox on that young devil of a handful long.
That has frayed many a tall thief from a rich purchase.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: This, and my money sir, keeps company;
Where one goes, the other must; assure your soul
They vowed never to part.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Hold, I beseech you sir.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: You rob a prisoners box, if you rob me, sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: There it is again .

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I knew it would never prosper with you;
Fie, rob a younger Brother, o take heed sir,
It is against nature that , perhaps your Father
Was one sir, or your Uncle, it should seem so
By the small means was left you, and less manners.
Go, keep you still before me, and do you hear me,
To pass away the time to the next Town,
I charge you sir, sing all your Songs for nothing ~~

sp.speaker: Lat.
sp.l: O horrible punishment. ~~

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Honest Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: How now, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Stand you in need of help?
I made all haste I could, my Master charged me.
A Knight of worship; he saw you first assaulted
From top of yonder hill.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Thanks honest friend.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I taste this trick already. ~~

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Look, he is gone sir,
Shall he be stopped; what is he?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Let him go sir;
He can rejoice in nothing, that is the comfort.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: You have your purse still then?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Aye, thanks fair fortune,
And this grim handful.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: We were all so frayed on you,
How my good Lady cried, O help the gentleman,
It is a good woman that : but you are too mild sir,
You should have marked him for a villain in faith
Before he had gone, having so sound a means too.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Why there is the jest man; he had once my purse.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: O villain, would you let him scape unmassacred?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Nay, hear me sir, I made him yield it straight again ,
And so hope bless me, with an uncharged Pistol.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: 'stroth I should laugh at that .

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: It was discharged Sir,
Before I meddled with it .

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: I am glad to hear it.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Why how now, What is your will ?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Ho, Latrocinio, Occulto, Silvio. ~~

body.stage: Enter Latrocinio and the rest, Occulto, Silvio, Fiducio

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What are you caught sir?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: The Pistol cannot speak.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: He was too young,
I ever thought he could not; yet I feared him.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: You have, found out ways too merciless to betray
Under the veil of friendship, and of charity.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Away sirs, bear him in to the next Cops, and strip him.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Brandino's Copps, the Justice?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Best of all sir, a man of law?
A Spider lies unsuspected in the corner of a buckram bag, man.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: What seek you sirs? take all and use no cruelty,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You shall have Songs enough.
How round the world goes, and everything that is in it,
The Tides of gold and silver, ebb and flow in a minute:
From the Usurer to his Sons, there a current swiftly runs,
From the Sons to Queans in chief, from the gallant to the Thief,
From the Thief unto his Host, from the Host to Husbandmen;
From the Country to the Court, and so it comes to us again .
How round the world goes, and everything that is in it,
The Tides of gold and silver, ebb and flow in a minute.

body.stage: Enter Philippa and Violetta above at the Window.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What time of night is it ?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Time of night do you call it?
It is so late, it is almost early Mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Fie on him, there is no looking for him then;
Why sure this Gentleman apprehends me not.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: It is happy then you are rid of such a fool Mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay sure Wench, if he find me not out in this
Which were a beaten path to any wise man,
I will never trust him with my reputation;
Therefore I made this trial of his wit,
If he cannot conceive what is good for himself,
He will worse understand what is good for me.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: But suppose Mistress. as it may be likely,
He never saw your letter?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How thou pliest me,
With suppositions? why I tell thee wench,
It is equally as impossible for my husband
To keep it from him, as to be young again ,
Or as his first wife knew him, which he brags on
For bearing children by him.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: There is no remedy then,
Francisco I must conclude is an Ass.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I would my letter, wench, were here again ,
I would know him wiser ere I sent him one;
And travail some five year first.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: So he had, need methinks,
To understand the words, methinks the words
Themselves should make him it , had he but the perseverance
Of a Cock sparrow, that will come at philip,
And can nor write, nor read poor fool, this Coxcomb
He can do both, and your name is but Philippa
And yet to see, if he can come when he is called.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: He never shall be called again for me sirrah .
Well, as hard as the world goes, we will have a Song wench,
We will not sit up for nothing.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: that is poor comfort though.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Better than any is brought, for aught I see yet? So set to your Lute.

sp.l: If in this question I propound to thee
Be any, any choice,
Let me have thy voice.
You shall most free.
Which hadst thou rather be
If thou might choose thy life,
A Fools, a fools Mistress,
Or an old man's wife?
The choice is hard, I know not which is best,
One ill you are bound to, and I think that is least .
But being not bound, my dearest sweet,
I could shake off the other.
Then as you lose your sport by one,
You lose your name by the other .
You counsel well, but love refuses, What good counsel often chooses.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I have got myself unbound yet: merciless villains,
I never felt such hardness since life dwelt in me;
It is for my sins: That light in yonder Window
That was my only comfort in the woods,
Which oft the trembling of a leaf would lose me,
Has brought me thus far, yet I cannot hope
For succour in this plight, the world is so pitiless,
And everyone will fear or doubt me now:
To knock will be too bold, I will to the gate,
And listen if I can hear any stirring.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Was ever man so crossed? no it is but sweat sure,
Or the dew dropping from the leaves above me,
I thought it had bled again : these wenching businesses
Are strange unlucky things, and fatal fooleries,
No marvel so many gallants die ere thirty,
It is able to vex out a man's heart in five year,
The crosses that belong to it : first arrested,
That set me back two mangy hours at lest ,
Yet that is a thing my heat could have forgiven,
Because arresting, in what kind soever,
Is a most Gentleman-like affliction:
But here, within a mile of the town forsooth,
And two mile off this place, when a man's oath
Might have been taken for his own security,
And his thoughts brisk, and set upon the business,
To light upon a roguey flight of Thieves,
Pox on them , here is the length of one of their whistles,
But one of my dear Rascals, I pursued so ,
The Gaol has him, and he shall bring out his fellows:
Had ever young man's love such crooked fortune?
I am glad I am so near yet; the Surgeon bad me to
Have a great care; I shall never think of that now.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: One of the Thieves come back again ? I will stand close;
He dares not wrong me now, so near the house,
And call in vain it is , till I see him offer it.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Slife, what should that be? a prodigious thing
Stands just as I should enter, in that shape too,
Which always appears terrible.
Whatever it be, it is made strong against me
By my ill purpose. For it is man's own sin
That puts on armour upon all his evils,
And gives them strength to strike him: were it less
Than what it is, my guilt would make it serve;
A wicked man's own shadow has distracted him:
Were this a business now to save an honour,
As it is to spoil one, I would pass this then
Stuck all hells horrors in thee: now I dare not.
Why may it not be the spirit of my Father
That loved this man so well, whom I make haste
Now to abuse? And I have been crossed about it
Most fearfully hitherto, if I well think on it ;
Scaped death but lately too, nay most miraculously;
And what does fond man venture all these ills for ,
That may so sweetly rest in honest peace?
For that which being obtained, is as he was
To his own sense, but removed nearer still
To death eternal: what delight has man
Now at this present, for his pleasant sin
Of yesterdays committing? alas, it is vanished,
And nothing but the sting remains within him.
The kind man bailed me too; I will not it now
If it were but only that : how blessed were man,
Might he but have his end appear still to him,
That he might read his actions in the event?
It would make him write true, though he never meant.
Whose Check soever thou art , Fathers, or Friends,
Or Enemies, I thank thee, peace requite thee;
Light, and the lighter Mistress both farewell.
He keeps his promise best that breaks with hell. ~~

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: He is gone to call the rest, and makes all speed,
I will knock whatever befalls, to please my fears,
For no compassion can be less than theirs.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: He is come, he is come; o are you come at last sir?
Make little noise, away, he will knock again else .

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I should have been at Istria by daybreak too,
Near to Valerias house the wealthy Widows,
There waits one purposely to do me good.
What will become of me?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: O, you are a sweet Gallant, this your hour?
Give me your hand; come, come sir, follow me,
I will bring you to light presently: softly, softly sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I should have given him up to all my thoughts
The dullest young man, if he had not found it;
So short of apprehension, and so worthless,
He were not fit for woman's fellowship:
I have been at cost too for a Banquet for him;
Why it would have killed my heart, and most especially
To think that man should have no more conceit;
I should have thought the worse of his wit forever,
And blamed mine own for too much forwardness.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: O Mistress, Mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How now, what is the news?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: O, I was out of my wits for a minute and a half.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hah?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: They are scarce settled yet Mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Do you ask that seriously?
Did you not hear me squeak?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How? sure thou art out of thy wits indeed.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: O, I am well now,
To what I was Mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why where is the gentleman?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: The gentleman is forthcoming, and a lovely one,
But not Francisco.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What sayst, not Francisco?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Pish, he is a coxcomb, think not on him Mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What is all this?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I have often heard you say, ye had rather have
A wise man in his shirt, than a Fool feathered,
And now fortune has sent you one, a sweet young gentleman,
Robbed even to nothing, but what first he brought with him,
The slaves had stripped him to the very shirt Mistress,
I think it was a shirt, I know not well,
For Gallants wear both nowadays.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: This is strange.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: But for a face a hand, and as much skin
As I durst look upon , he is a most sweet one;
Francisco is a child of Egypt to him:
I could not but in pity to the poor gentleman,
Fetch him down one of my old Masters Suits.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: It was charitably done,

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: You would say Mistress, if you had seen him as I did.
Sweet youth, I will be sworn Mistress he is the loveliest
Properest young gentleman, and so you will say yourself,
If my Masters clothes do not spoil him, that is all the fear now,
I would it had been your luck to have seen him
without them, but for scarring on you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Go, prithee fetch him in whom thou commendest so .
Since fortune sends him, surely we will make much on him;
And better he deserves our love, and welcome,
Than the respectless fellow it was prepared for ;
Yet if he please mine eye never so happily,
I will have trial of his wit, and faith,
Before I make him partner with my honour.
It was just Francisco's case, and he deceived me;
I will take more heed of the next for it ; perhaps now
To furnish his distress, he will appear
Full of fair promising Courtship; but I will prove him then
For a next meeting, when he needs me not,
And see what he performs then when the storm
Of his so rude misfortunes is blown over,
And he himself again : A distressed man's flatteries
Are like vows made in drink, or bonds in prison,
There is poor assurance in them : when he is from me,
And in his own power, then I shall see his love.
By'th'mass here he comes.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Never was star crossed gentleman
More happy in a courteous virgins love,
Than I in yours.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I am sorry they are no better for you,
I wished them handsomer, and more in fashion,
But truly Sir, our house affords it not:
There is a Suit of our Clerks, hangs in the garret,
But that is far worse than this, if I may judge
With modesty of men's matters.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I deserve not
This, dear, and kind gentlewoman, is yond your Mistress?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why trust me, here is my Husband young again ,
It is no sin to welcome you, Sweet gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I am so much indebted, courteous Lady,
To the unmatched charity of your house,
My thanks are such poor things they would but shame me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Beshrew thy heart for bringing of him: I fear me
I have found wit enough already in him.
If I could truly but resolve myself
My husband was thus handsome at nineteen,
'stroth I should think the better of him at fourscore now.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Nay Mistress, what would he be, were he in fashion,
A hempen curse on those that put him out of it ,
That now appears so handsome, and so comely in clothes
Able to make a man an unbeliever,
And good for nothing but for shift, or so
If a man chance to fall in the ditch with better?
This is the best, that ever I marked in them ,
A man may make him ready in such clothes
Without a candle.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Aye for shame of himself Wench.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: My Master does it oft in winter mornings,
And never sees himself till he be ready.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: No , nor then neither, as he should do Wench.
I am sorry gentle Sir, we cannot show you
A courtesy, in all points answerable
To your undoubted worth: your name I crave sir.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Ansaldo Lady.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: It is a noble name Sir.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: The most unfortunate now.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: So do I think truly
As long as that Suit is on .

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: The most unfitting,
And unprovidest sir of all our courtesies,
I do presume is that you have, past already,
Your pardon but for that , and we are encouraged.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: My faithful service, Lady.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Please you Sir
To taste the next a poor slight Banquet, for sure I think you were
Unluckily prevented of your supper sir.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: My fortune makes me more than amends Lady,
In your sweet kindness, which so nobly shown to me,
It makes me bold to speak my occasions to you:
I am this morning, that with clearness now
So cheerfully hastens me, to meet a Friend
Upon my states establishing, and the place
Ten mile from hence: o , I am forced unwillingly
To crave your leave for it , which done I return
In service plentiful.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Is it so important?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: If I should fail, as much as my undoing.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I think too well of you, to undo you sir,
Upon this small acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: My great happiness.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But when should I be sure of you here again sir?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: As fast as speed can possibly return me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You will not fail?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: May never wish go well with me then.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: There is to bear charges sir.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Courtesy dwells in you.
I brought my horse up with me from the woods,
that is all the good they left me, against their wills too,
May your kind breast never want comfort Lady,
But still supplied, as liberally as you give.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Farewell sir, and be faithful.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Time shall prove me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: In my opinion now, this young man's likeliest
To keep his word, he is modest, wise, and courteous;
He has the language of an honest soul in him:
A woman's reputation may lie safe there,
I am much deceived else, he has a faithful eye
If it be well observed.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Good speed be with thee sir;
He puts him to it in faith.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Violetta.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Alas, what have we done wench?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: What is the matter Mistress?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Run, run, call him again ; he must stay tell him,
Though it be upon his undoing, we are undone else,
Your Masters clothes, their known the Country over.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Now by this light that is true, and well remembered
But there is no calling of him, he is out of sight now.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O what will people think?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: What can they think Mistress?
The Gentleman has the worst of it : were I he now
I would make this ten mile, forty mile about
Before I would ride through any market town with them .

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Will he be careful thinkst?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: My life for yours Mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I shall long mightily to see him again .

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: And so shall I, I shall never laugh till then.

body.stage: Enter Ricardo and 2 Suitor at one door, and Valeria and 1 Suitor at another door.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: It goes well hitherto, my sweet Protector.

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: Aye, and shall still to the end, to the end my honey,
Wherefore have I enough, but to have it go well sir?

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: My whole State on it ; thou overthrowest him Widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I hope well still sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: Hope? be certain Wench:
I make no question now, but thou art mine,
As sure as if I had thee in thy night gear.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: B'r'lady, that I doubt Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: O it is clear wench
By one thing that I marked.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What is that good sweet sir?

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: A thing that never failed me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Good sir, what?

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: I heard our Counsellor speak a word of comfort
Invita voluntate hah, that is he wench,
The word of words, the precious chief in faith.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Invita voluntate what is the meaning sir?

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: Nay there I leave you, but assure you thus much,
I never heard him speak that word in my life,
But the cause went on his side, that I marked ever.

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: Do, do , and spare not: thou wouldst talk with her .

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Yes, with your leave, and liking.

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: Do, my adoption,
My chosen child, if thou holdest so obedient
Sure thou wilt live, and cozen all my kindred.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: A Child's part in your love, that is my ambition sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: Go, and deserve it then: please me well now;
I love wrangling a-life Boy; there is my delight,
I have no other venery but vexation,
That is all my honey now: smartly now to her ,
I have enough and I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: This need not have been Widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You say right sir.
No , nor your treachery, your close conspiracy
Against me for my wealth, need not have been neither.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I had your fairly, I scorn treachery
To your woman that I never meant to marry,
Much more to you whom I reserved for wife.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How, wife?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Aye, Wife, Wife, Widow, be not ashamed of it ,
It is the best calling ever woman came to ,
And all your grace indeed, brag as you list.

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I grant you sir, But not to be your wife.

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: O, o .

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Not mine? I think it is the best bargain
That ever thou madest in thy life, or ever shall again ,
When my head is laid: but that is not yet this threescore year,
Let us talk of nearer matters.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: you are as near sir
As ever you are like to be, if Law can right me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Now before conscience, you are a wilful housewife.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Aye, and I fear you spend my goods lavishly.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Your goods?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I shall miss much I doubt me,
When I come to look over the Inventory.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I will give you my word you shall sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Look to it Widow,
A night may come will call you to accompt for it .

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O if you had me now sir in this heat
I do but think how you would be revenged on me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Aye, may I perish else; if I would not get
Three Children at a birth, and I could of thee.

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: Take off your youngster there.

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: Take off your Widow first,
He shall have the last word, I pay for it dearly;
To her again sweet Boy, that side is the weaker.
I have enough, and I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O Brother see I am up to the ears in law here;
Look, Copy upon Copy.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: It were grief enough if a man did but hear of it
But I am in pain to see it .

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What sore eyes still Brother?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Worse, and worse Sister; the old woman's water
Does me no good.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why, it has helped many sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: It helps not me I am sure ~~

sp.speaker: Marti.
sp.l: O, o .

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What ails Martino too?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O, o , the toothache, the toothache.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Ah poor worm, this he endures for me now.
There beats not a more mutual pulse of passion,
In a kind husband when his wife breeds child,
Than in Martino; I have marked it ever,
He breeds all my pains in his teeth still: and to quit me,
It is his eyetooth too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Aye, Aye, Aye, aye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Where did I hear late of a skilful fellow,
Good for all kind of Maladies? true, true sir,
His flag hangs out in town here, in the Cross Inn,
With admirable cures of all conditions,
It shows him a great travelling, and learned Empiric.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: We will both to him Martino.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Hark you Brother,
Perhaps you may prevail, as one indifferent.

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: Aye, about that sweet Widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: True; speak low sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Well, what is the business, say, say.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Marry this Brother.
Call the young man aside, from the old wolf there,
And whisper in his ear a thousand dollars
If he will vanish, and let fall the Suit,
And never put us to no more cost and trouble.

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: Say me those words good sir, I will make them worth
A chain of gold to you, at your Sisters wedding.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I shall do much for that .

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Welcome sweet heart,
Thou comest most happily, I am bold to send for thee
To make a purpose good.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I take delight forsooth
In any such employment.

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: Good wench trust me

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: How Sir, let fall the Suit? 'Slife I will go naked first.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: A thousand Dollars sir, think upon them.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Why they are but a thousand Dollars, when they are thought on .

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: A good round sum.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: A good round Widow is better,
There is meat and money too. I have been bought
Out of my lands, and yielded, but (sir) scorn
To be bought out of my affection.

sp.speaker: Bra.
