sp.l: Why here is even just my University spirit,
I prized a piece of red Deer, above gold then.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: My Patron would be mad, if he should hear of it .

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I pray what is good Sir, for a wicked tooth?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Hanged, drawn, and quartering; is it a hollow one?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Aye, it is a hollow one.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Then take the powder
Of a burnt Warrant, mixed with oil of Felon.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why sure you mock me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: 'stroth I think I do sir.

sp.speaker: 2. Suter.
sp.l: Come hither honey; What is the news in whispers?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: He will not be bought out.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No ? that is strange Brother.
Pray take a little pains about this project then,
And try what that effects.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I like this better;
Look you sweet Gentles, see what I produce here
For amities sake, and peace, to end all controversy;
This Gentlewoman my charge left by her friends,
Whom for her person, and her portion,
I could bestow most richly, but in pity
To her affection, which lies bent at you sir,
I am content to yield to her desire.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: At me?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: But for this jar, it had never been offered.
I bring you flesh, and money, a rich heir,
And a Maid too, and that is a thing worth thanks, sir:
Nay, one that has rid fifteen mile this morning
For your love only .

sp.speaker: 2. Suter.
sp.l: Honey, hearken after her ;
Being rich, I can have all my money there:
Ease my purse well, and never wage law further.
I have enough, yet I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Do you love me forsooth?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: O infinitely.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I do not ask thee, that I meant to have thee,
But only to know what came in thy head to love me.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: My time was come sir, that is all I can say.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Alas poor soul, where didst thou love me first prithee?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: In happy hour be it spoke, out at a window sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: A window? prithee clap it too, and call it in again :
What was I doing then should make thee love me?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Twirling your band string, which methought became you so generously well.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: It was a good quality to choose a husband for : That love was likely to be tied in Matrimony, that begun in a band string: yet I have known as much come to pass ere now upon a tassel. Fare you well Sister; I may be cozened in a Maid, I cannot in a Widow.

sp.speaker: 2. Suter.
sp.p: Art thou come home again ; stickest thou there still? I will defend thee still then.

sp.speaker: 1. Suter.
sp.l: Sir your malice
Will have enough of it .

sp.speaker: 2. Suter.
sp.l: I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: 1. Sut.
sp.l: Beggary will prove the sponge.

sp.speaker: 2. Sut.
sp.l: Sponge in thy gascoyns,
Thy gally-gascoyns there.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Hah brave Protector.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I thought it would come to open Wars again ,
Let them agree as they will ; two testy Fops,
I will have a care of mine eyes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I, of my chops.

body.stage: Enter Latrocinio and Occulto a Banner of Cures and Diseases hung out.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Away, out with the Banner, send us good luck today.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: I warrant you; your name is spread Sir, for an Empiric.
There is an old Mason troubled with the Stone,
Has sent to you this morning for your counsel,
He would have ease fain.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Marry I cannot blame him sir.
But how he will come by it , there lies the question,

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: You must do somewhat sir, for he is swollen most piteously,
Has urine in him now was brewed last March.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: It will be rich gear for Dyers.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: I would it were come to that sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Let me see, I will send him a whole Musket charge of Gunpowder.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Gunpowder? what sir, to break the stone?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Aye by my faith sir,
It is the likeliest thing I know to it ,
I am sure it breaks stone walls, and Castles down,
I see no reason, but it should break the stone.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Nay, use your pleasure sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: 'stroth, if that do not
I have nothing else that will .

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: I know that too.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why then thou art a Coxcomb to make question of it .
Go call in all the rest, I have employment for them.
When the highways grow thin with Travellers,
And few Portmanteaus stirring, as all trades
Have their dead time we see; Thee very, poor takings,
And Lechery cold doings, and so forwards still;
Then do I take my Inn, and those Curmudgeons,
Whose Purses I can never get abroad,
I take them at more ease here in my chamber,
And make them come to me, it is more state-like too:
Hang him that has but one way to his trade,
He is like a mouth that eats but on one side,
And half cozens his belly, specially if he dine among Shavers,
sp.stage: Enter all the rest Silvio, Stratio, Fiducio
sp.l: And both handed feeders? Stratio, Silvio, and Fiducio,
I will have none left out, there is parts for you.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: For us ? pray let us have them .

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Change yourselves
With all speed possible into several shapes
Far from your own, as you a Farmer sir,
A Grazier you, and you may be a Miller.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: O no , a Miller comes too near a Thief,
That may spoil all again .

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Some Country Taylor, then.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: That is near enough b'r'lady, yet I will venture that ;
The Miller is a white Devil, he wears his theft
Like Innocence in badges most apparently
Upon his nose, sometimes between his lips;
The Tailor modestly between his legs.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why pray, do you present that modest thief then,
And hark you, for the purpose.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: It will improve you sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: It will get believers, believe that my Masters,
Repute and confidence, and make all things clearer;
When you see any come, repair you to me
As samples of my skill; there are few arts
But have their shadows Sirs to set them off;
Then where the Art itself, is but a shadow
What need is there my Friends? make haste away sirs.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Where are you Sir?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Not far man; What is the news?

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: The old Justice sir, whom we robbed once by Moonlight,
And bound his man and he in haycock time
With a rope made of horse meat, and in pity
Left their Mares by them , which I think ere midnight
Did eat their hay bound Masters both at liberty, ~~

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: 'Slife, what of him man?

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: He is enquiring earnestly
For the great man of art ; indeed for you sir:
Therefore withdraw sweet sir; make yourself dainty now,
And that is three parts of any profession.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I have enough of it .

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: How now, what thing is this?
Now by this light, the second part of the Justice
Newly revived, with never a hair on his face,
It should be the first rather by his smoothness,
But I have known the first part written last:
It is he, or let me perish, the young Gentleman
We robbed, and stripped, but I am far from knowledge now.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: One word I pray Sir.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: With me gentle Sir?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Was there not lately seen about these parts sir
A knot of fellows, whose conditions
Are privily suspected?

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Why do you ask Sir?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: There was a poor young gentleman robbed last night.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Robbed?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Stripped of all in faith.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: O beastly Rascals.
Alas what was he?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Look on me, and know him sir.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Hardhearted villains, strip? troth when I saw you
Methought those clothes were never made for you sir.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Want made me glad of them.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: God send you better fortunes sir:
That we may have about with you once again .

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I thank you for your wish of love, kind sir.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: It is with my heart in faith; now store of coin
And better clothes be with you.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: There is some honest yet
And charitably minded: how, what is here to do ?
Here within this place is cured
All the griefs that were ever endured.
Nay there thou liest, I endured one last night,
Thou canst not cure this morning; a strange Promiser.
Palsy, Gout, Hydropic Humour,
Breath that sticks beyond perfumer,
Fistula in ano, Ulcer, Megrum,
Or what disease soever beleaguer them ,
Stone, Rupture, Squinancie, Imposthume,
Yet too dear it shall not cost them .
That is conscionably said in faith.
In brief, you cannot I assure you
Be unsound so fast, as I can cure you.
B'r'lady, you shall pardon me, I will not try it sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Martino is not yond my hinder parts?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, and your fore parts too Sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I trow so ,
I never saw my hind parts in my life else,
No , nor my fore ones neither: what are you sir?
Are you a Justice pray?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: A Justice? No truly.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: How came this Suit to you then?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: How, this Suit?
Why must he needs be a Justice sir, that wears it?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: You will find it so : it was made for nobody else.
I paid for it .

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: O strange fortune, I have undone
The charitable woman.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: He will be gone.
Martino hold him fast, I will call for aid.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Hold me? o curse of fate!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O Master, Master.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: What ails Martino?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: In my conscience
Has beat out the wrong tooth, I feel it now,
Three degrees off.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: O slave, spoiled a fine Penman.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: He lacked good manners though: lay hands on me?
I scorn all the deserts, that belong to it .

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why how now? what is the broil?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: The man of art
I take you sir to be.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I am the professor
Of those slight cures you read of in the Banner.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Our business was to you most skilful sir,
But in the way to you, right worshipful
I met a thief.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: A thief?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: With my clothes on sir,
Let but the Hose be searched, I will pawn my life
There is yet the Tailors bill in one of the pockets,
And a white thimble that I found in moon light,
Thou sawest me when I put it in Martino.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Oy, oy.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: O, has spoiled the worthiest Clark that ever drew Warrant here.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Sir, you are a stranger, but I must deal plain with you,
That Suit of clothes must needs come only to you.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I dare not say which way, that is my affliction.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Is not your worships name Seignior Brandino sir?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: It has been so , these threescore year and upwards.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I heard there was a robbery done last night
Near to your house.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: You heard a truth then sir,
And I the man was robbed.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ah that is too gross
Send him away for fear of farther mischief,
I do not like him, he is a cunning knave.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I want but aid.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Within there.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Seize upon that impudent thief.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Then hear me speak.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Away;
I will neither hear thee speak, nor wear those clothes again ,
To prison with the varlet.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: How am I punished?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I will make thee bring out all, before I leave thee.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You have took an excellent course with this bold villain sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I am sworn for service to the Commonwealth sir,
What are these, learned sir?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O they are my patients.
Good morrow, Gout, Rupture, and Palsy.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: It is farewell Gout almost, I thank your worship.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What no you cannot part so soon, I hope?
You came but lately to me.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: But most happily,
I can go near to leap sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What you cannot?
Away I say, take heed, be not too venturous though,
I have had you but three days, remember that .

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Those three are better than three hundred sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Yet again ?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Ease takes pleasure to be known sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You with the rupture there hernia in scrotum
Pray let me see your space this morning, walk sir,
I will take your distance strait: it was F. O. yesterday:
Ah sirrah , here is a simple alteration,
Secondo gradu ye F. U. already,
Here is a most happy change; be of good comfort sir,
Your knees are come, within three inches now
Of one another ; by tomorrow noon
I will make them kiss, and jostle.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: God bless your worship.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: You have a hundred prayers in a morning sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: in faith we have a few to pass away the day with:
Taylor, you had a stitch.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: O good your worship
I have had none since Easter: were I rid
But of this whoreson Palsy, I were happy;
I cannot thread my needle.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: No , that is hard,
I never marked so much.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: It comes by fits sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Alas poor man: what would your worship say now
To see me help this fellow at an instant?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: And make him firm from shaking?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: As a steeple,
From the disease of it .

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: It is to me miraculous.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You, with your whoremaster disease, come hither;
Here, take me this round glass, and hold it steadfast,
Yet more sir, yet I say; so .

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Admirable.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Go, live, and thread thy needle.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Here Martino:
Alas poor Fool, his mouth is full of praises
And cannot utter them .

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: No , what is the malady?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: The fury of a tooth.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: A tooth? ha , ha ,
I thought it had been some Gangrene, Fistula,
Canker, or Ramex.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: No , it is enough as it is sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My man shall ease that straight, sit you down there sir,
Take the tooth sirrah , daintily, insensibly:
But what is your worships malady, that is for me sir?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Marry pray look you sir: your worships Counsel
About mine eyes.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Sore eyes? that is nothing too sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: B'r'Lady I that feel it think it somewhat.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Have you no Convulsions? pricking aches sir,
Rupture, or Apostemates?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: No by my faith sir,
Nor do I desire to have them .

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Those are cures,
There do I win my fame sir: quickly sirrah ,
Reach me the eye cup hither: do you make water well sir?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I am all well there.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You feel no grief in the kidney.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Sound, sound, sound sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O here is a breath sir, I must talk withal
One of these mornings.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: There I think in faith,
I am to blame indeed, and my wife's words
Are come to pass sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O, o , it is not that , it is not that
It is the next beyond it; there, there, there.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: The best have their mistakings: now I will fit you sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: What is that sweet Sir, that comforts with his coolness?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O sovereign goer: wink hard, and keep it in sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O, o , o .

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Nay, here he goes, one twitch more, and he comes sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Ah, ho.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Spit out. I told you he was gone sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: How cheers Martino?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O, I can answer you now Master,
I feel great ease sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: So do I Martino.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am rid of a sore burden, for my part Master
Of a scaled little one.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Please but your worship now
To take three drops of the rich water with you,
I will undertake your man shall cure you sir
At twice in your own Chamber.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Shall he so sir?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I will uphold him in it .

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then will I it sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: How lively your man is now?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O I am so light methinks
Over I was.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: What is it contents your worship?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Even what your worship please. I am not mercenary.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: My purse is gone Martino.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: How, your purse sir?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: It is gone in faith: I have been among some Rascals.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And that is a thing
I ever gave you warning of Master, you care not
What company you run into.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Lend me some money: chide me anon I prithee.
A pox on them for vipers, they have sucked blood of me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O Master.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: How now man?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My purse is gone too.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: How? I will never take warning more of thee while I live then, thou art an Hypocrite, and art not fit to give good counsel to thy Master, that canst not keep from ill company thyself.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: This is most strange sir: both your purses gone .

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir, I had my hand on mine, when I came in .

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Are you but sure of that ; o would you were.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: As I am of ease.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Then, they are both gone one way, be that your comfort.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Aye but what way is that sir?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: That close knave in your Clothes has got them both,
It is well you have clapped him fast.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Why that is impossible.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O tell not me sir: I have known purses gone ,
And the Thief stand, and look one full in the face,
As I may do your Worship, and your man now.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nay, that is most certain Master.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I will make
That Rascal in my clothes answer all this then,
And all the robberies that have been done
Since the Moon changed; get you home first Martino
And know if any of my wives things are missing,
Or any more of mine: tell her he is taken,
And by that token he has took both our purses.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: that is an ill token Master.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: that is all one sir,
She must have that or nothing, for I am sure
The Rascal has left nothing else for a Token.
Begone, make haste again ; and meet me pass of the way.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I will hang the villain,
If it were for nothing but the Sauce he gave me.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Sir, I depart ashamed of my requital,
And leave this seal ring with you as a pledge
Of further thankfulness.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: No , I beseech you sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Indeed you shall sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O, your worships word sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: You shall have my word too, for a rare gentleman
As ever I met withal.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Clear sight be with you sir;
If Conduit water, and my Hostess Milk
That comes with the ninth child now, may afford it.
'Slife, I feared none but thee, my villainous tooth drawer,

sp.speaker: Occult.
sp.l: There was no fear of me; I have often told you
I was bound Prentice to a Barber once,
But ran away in the second year.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Aye marry,
That made thee give a pull at the wrong tooth.
And me afraid of thee: what have we there sirs?

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: Some threescore Dollars in the Masters purse,
And sixteen in the Clerks, a Silver seal,
Two or three Amber beads, and four blank Warrants.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Warrants? where be they? the best news came yet.
By'th'mass here is his hand, and here is his Seal I thank him,
This comes most luckily: one of our fellows
Was took last night, we will set him first at liberty,
And other good Boys after him: and if he
In the old Justices Suit, whom he robbed lately,
Will come off roundly, we will set him free too.

sp.speaker: Occ.
sp.l: That were a good deed in faith, we may in pity.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: There is nothing done merely for pity noawadays,
Money or Ware must help too.

body.stage: Song, in parts by the Thieves

sp.l: Give me fortune, give me health,
Give me freedom, I will get wealth.
Who complains his fate is amiss,
When he has the wide world his?
He that has the Devil in fee,
Can have but all, and so have we .
Give us fortune, give us Health,
Give us freedom, we will get wealth.
In every Hamlet, Town and City,
He has lands, that was born witty.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How well this Gentleman keeps his promise too?
Sure there is no trust in man.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: They are all Francisco's
that is my opinion Mistress: Fools, or false ones.
He might have had the honesty yet in faith
To send my Masters clothes home.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Aye those clothes.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Colliers come by the door every day Mistress,
Nay, this is Market day too, Poulterers, Butchers,
They would have lain most daintily in a Pannier,
And kept Veal from the wind.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Those clothes much trouble me.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: in faith, if he were a gentleman as he seemed to be,
They would trouble him too I think;
Methinks he should have small desire to keep them .

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: in faith and less pride to wear them , I should think wench,
Unless he kept them as a testimony
For after times to show what misery
He past in his young days, and then weep over them .

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Weep Mistress? nay sure methinks he should not weep for laughing.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Martino? o we are spoiled wench, are they come then?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Mistress, be of good cheer, I have excellent news for you, comfort your heart, what have you to breakfast Mistress, you shall have all again , I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What says he Wench?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I am loath to understand him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Give me a note of all your things sweet Mistress,
You shall not lose a hair, take it of my word
We have him safe enough.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O alas, sweet wench
This man talks fearfully.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: And I know not what yet
that is the worst Mistress.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Can you tell me pray,
Whether the Rascal has broke ope my desk or no ,
There is a fine little barrel of pome-citrons
Would have served me this seven year, o , and my fig cheese.
The fig of everlasting obloquy
Go with him if he have eat it, I will make haste
He cannot eat it all yet, he was taken Mistress
Grossly, and beastly, how do you think in faith?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I know not sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Troth in my Masters clothes,
Would any thief but a beast been taken so ?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Wench, wench.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I have grief enough of mine own to tend Mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Did he confess the robbery?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O no , no Mistress
He is a young cunning Rascal, he confessed nothing;
While we were examining on him, he took away
My Masters purse and mine, but confessed nothing still.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: That is but some slanderous injury raised against him.
Came not your Master. with you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No sweet Mistress.
I must make haste and meet him, pray dispatch me then.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I have looked over all with special heedfulness,
There is nothing missed, I can assure you sir
But that Suit of your Masters.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am right glad of it
sp.p: That Suit would hang him yet I would not have him hanged in that Suit though, it will disgrace my Masters fashion forever, and make it as hateful as yellow bands.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O what shall us do wench?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: The poor young Gentleman could not keep his promise.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Alas sweet man, he has confessed nothing you wench.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: That shows his constancy, and love to you Mistress:
But you must it of force, there is no help for it ,
The truth can neither shame nor hurt you much,
Let them make what they can of it , it were sin and pity in faith
To cast away so sweet a Gentleman,
For such a pair of infidel hose and doublet,
I would not hang a Jew for a whole wardrobe of them .

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thou sayst true wench.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: O, o , they are come again Mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Seignior Ansaldo?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: The same mightily crossed Lady,
But past hope freed again by a Doctors means,
A man of art , I know not justly what indeed,
But pity, and the fortunate gold you gave me,
Wrought my release between them .

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Met you not
My husbands man?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I took such strange ways Lady
I hardly met a creature.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O most welcome

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: But how shall we bestow him now we have him Mistress?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Alas, that is true.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Martino may come back again .

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Step you into that little Chamber speedily sir,
And dress him up in one of my Gowns and head tires
His youth will well endure it.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: That will be admirable.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay it , it quickly then, and cut that Suit
Into a hundred pieces, that it may never be known again .

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: A hundredth? nay ten thousand at the least Mistress.
For if there be a piece of that Suit, left, as big as my nail,
The deed will come out, it is worse than a murder,
I fear it will never be hid.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Away, do your endeavour, and dispatch wench,
I have thought upon a way of certain safety,
And I may keep him while I have him too,
Without suspicion now: I have heard of the like :
A Gentleman, that for a Ladies love
Was thought six months her woman, tended on her
In her own garments, and she being a Widow,
Lay night by night with her in way of comfort,
Marry in conclusion match they did together,
Would I had a copy of the same conclusion:
He is come himself now, if thou beest a happy wench
Be fortunate in thy speed, I will delay time
With all the means I can: o welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I will speak to you anon wife, and kiss you shortly,
Cocksey-down, Mem-berrie I am very busy yet:
Her Manor house at Well-dun

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What is that good sir?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: The widows your sweet Sisters deed of gift;
She has made all her estate over to me wench:
She will be too hard for them all: and now come buss me
Good luck after thieves handsel.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O it is happy Sir
You have him fast.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I have laid him safe enough wench.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I was so lost in joy at the report on it
I quite forgot one thing to tell Martino.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: What is that sweet blood?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: He, and his villains sir
Robbed a sweet Gentlewoman last night.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: A Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay, most uncivilly and basely stripped her sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: O barbarous slaves.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I was even fain for womanhood's sake
(Alas) and charities, to receive her in ,
And cloth her poor wants in a Suit of mine.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: It was most religiously done: I long for her ;
Who have I brought to see thee thinkst thou woman?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay Sir, I know not.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Guess, I prithee heartily:
An enemy of thine.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: That I hope you have not sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: But all was done in jest: he cries thee mercy,
Francisco sirrah .

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O; I think not on him.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: That Letter was but writ to try thy constancy,
He confessed all to me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Joy on him sir,
So far am I from malice, look you sir;
Welcome sweet Seignior; but I will never trust you sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Faith I am beholding to thee wife, for this.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Methinks, I enter now this house with joy,
Sweet peace, and quietness of conscience,
I wear no guilty blush upon my cheek
For a sin stamped last midnight: I can talk now
With that kind man, and not abuse him inwardly.
With any scornful thought made of his shame:
What a sweet being is an honest mind?
It speaks peace to itself,, and all mankind.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Martino.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Master.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: There is another robbery done sirrah ,
By the same party.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What? your worship mocks,
Under correction.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I forgot to tell thee
He robbed a lovely Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O Pagan,
This fellow will be stoned to death with Pipkins,
Your women in the Suburbs will so maul him
With broken crewzes, and pitchers without ears,
sp.stage: Enter Ansaldo as Martia and ; Violetta
sp.l: He will never die alive, that is my opinion.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Look you your judgments Gentlemen, yours especially
Seignior Francisco whose mere object now
Is woman at these years, that is the eye Saint I know
Amongst young Gallants, Husband, you have a glimpse too;
You offer half an eye, as old as you are,

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: B'r'lady better wench: an eye, and a half I trow,
I should be sorry else.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What think you now sirs
Is it not a goodly manly Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Beshrew my heart else wife.
Pray soft a little Seignior you are but my guest remember,
I am Master. of the house, I will have the first buss.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But Husband, it is the courtesy of all places
To give a stranger ever the first bit.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: In Woodcock or so , but there is no heed to be taken in Mutton;
We commonly fall so roundly to that we forget ourselves:
I am sorry for thy fortune, but thou art welcome Lady

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My Master kisses, as I have heard a hackney man
Cheer up his Mare, chap, chap.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I have him fast Lady, and he shall lie by it close,

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: You cannot do me a greater pleasure Sir,

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I am happily glad of it .

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Methinks there is somewhat whispers in my soul,
This is the hour, I must begin my acquaintance
With honest love, and banish all loose thoughts;
My fate speaks to me from the modest eye
Of yon sweet Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Wench, Wench.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Pish, hold in your breath Mistress,
If you be seen to laugh, you spoil all presently,
I keep it in with all the might I have ~~ puh.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Pray what young gentleman is that sir?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: An honest boy in faith,
And came of a good kind: dost like him Lady,
I would thou hadst him, if thou beest not promised,
He is worth ten thousand Dollars.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: By this light Mistress, my Master will go near to make a match anon, methinks I dream of admirable sport Mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Peace, thou art a drab.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Come hither now Francisco.
I have known the time, I have had a better stomach;
Now I can dine with looking upon meat.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: That face deserved a better fortune Lady
Than last nights rudeness showed.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: We cannot be
Our choosers sir in our own destiny.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I return better pleased, than when I went.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And could that beastly Imp rob you forsooth?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Most true forsooth,
I will not altogether sir, disgrace you,
Because you look half like a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And that is the Mothers half.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: There is my hand for you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I swear you could not give me anything
I love better, a hand gets me my living;
O sweet symon-peel.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: May I request a modest word or two Lady
In private with you?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: With me sir?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: To make it sure from all suspect of injury,
Or unbeseeming privacy, which heaven knows
Is not my aim now, I will entreat this gentleman
For an ear witness unto all our conference.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Why so , I am content Sir,

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: So am I Lady ~~

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O Master, here is a rare Bedfellow for my Mistress tonight,
For you know we must both out of Town again .

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: That is true Martino.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I do but think how they will lie telling of tales together
The prettiest.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: The prettilyest indeed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Their tongues will never lyn wagging Master.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Never Martino, never .

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Take heed you be not heard.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I fear you most Mistress.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Me fool? ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Why look you Mistress: faith you are faulty, ha, ha,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Well said in faith, where lies the fault now gossip.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: O for a husband; I shall burst with laughing else ,
This house is able to spoil any Maid.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I will be revenged now soundly of Francisco
For failing me when time was.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Are you there Mistress? I thought you would not forget that
However, a good turn disappointed is ever the last thing
That a woman forgives, she will scarce it when she is speechless,
Nay, though she hold up her whole hand for all other injuries,
She will forgive that but with one finger.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I will vex his heart as much as he mocked mine.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: But that may mar your hopes too, if our gentlewoman be known to be a man.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Not as I will work it;
I would not lose this sweet revenge methinks
For a whole fortnight of the old man's absence,
Which is the sweetest benefit next to this:
Why how now sir, what course take you for laughing?
We are undone for one.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Faith with great pain,
Stifle it, and keep it in : I have no receipt for it .
But pray, in sadness say; What is the Gentleman,
I never knew his like for tedious urgings,
He will receive no answer.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Would he would not Sir.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Says I am ordained for him: merely for him,
And that his wiving fate speaks in me to him;
Will force on me a jointure speedily
Of some seven thousand Dollars.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Would thou hadst them sir: I know he can and he will .

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: For wonders pity; What is this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: in faith shall I tell you sir,
One that would make an excellent honest husband
For her that is a just Maid at one and twenty:
For on my conscience he has his Maidenhead yet.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Fie, out upon him beast.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sir, if you love me.
Give way but to one thing I shall request of you.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Your courtesies you know may lay commands on me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Then at his next solicitings, let a consent
Seem to come from you; It will make noble sport sir,
We will get jointure and all; but you must bear
Yourself most affable to all his purposes.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I can do that .

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Aye, and take heed of laughing.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I have bide the worst of that already Lady.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Peace, set your countenance then; for here he comes.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: There is no middle continent in this passion,
I feel it since, it must be love, or death
It was ordained for one.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Seignior Francisco
I am sorry it was your fortune, in my house sir,
To have so violent a stroke come to you:
The gentlewoman is a stranger pray be counselled sir,
Till you hear further of her Friends and portion.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: It is only but her love that I desire,
She comes most rich in that .

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But be advised though,
I think she is a rich heir, but see the proof sir,
Before you make her such a generous Jointure.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: It is mine, and I will do it .

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: She shall be yours too,
If I may rule her then.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: You speak all sweetness.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: She likes your person well, I tell you so much,
But take no note I said so .

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Not a word.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Come Lady, come, the gentleman is desertful,
And on my conscience honest.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Blame me not, I am a Maid, and fearful.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Never truth came perfecter from man.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Give her a lip taste.
That she herself, may praise it.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Yea, a match in faith: my house is lucky for them
Now Martino.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Master, the Widow has the day.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: The day?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: She has overthrown my youngster.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Precious tidings.
Clap down four Woodcocks more.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: They are all at hand Sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: What both her adversaries too.

body.stage: Enter Valeria, Ricardo and two Suitors

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: They are come sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Go bid the Cook serve in two geese in a dish.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I like your conceit Master beyond utterance.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Welcome sweet Sister; which is the man must have you.
I would welcome nobody else .

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: Come to me then sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Are you here faith, my chain of gold? I am glad of it .

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I wonder you can have the face to follow me,
That have so prosecuted things against me,
But I have resolved myself it is done to spite me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: O dearth of truth.

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: Nay, do not spoil thy hair,
Hold, hold I say, I will get thee a Widow somewhere.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: If hand and faith be nothing for a Contract,
What shall man hope?

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: It was wont to be enough, Honey.
When there was honest meaning amongst Widows,
But since your bribes came in , it is not allowed
A contract without gifts to bind it fast,
Everything now must have a feeling first
Do I come near you Widow?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No indeed sir,
Nor ever shall I hope: and for your comfort sir,
That sought all means to entrap me for my wealth,
Had Law unfortunately put you upon me,
You had lost your labour, all your aim, and hopes sir:
Here stands the honest Gentleman my Brother
To whom I have made a deed of gift of all.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Aye that she has in faith, I thank her Gentlemen
Look you here sirs.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I must not look for pleasures
That give more grief if they prove false, or fail us
Than ever they gave joy.

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: Have you serve me so widow

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: I am glad thou hast her not, laugh at him honey; ha , ha.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I must take one that loves me for myself :
Here is an old Gentleman looks not after wealth
But virtue, manners, and conditions.

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: Yes by my faith: I must have Lordships too Widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How sir?

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: Your manners, virtue, and conditions Widow
Are pretty things within doors, I like well of them ,
But I must have somewhat with outlying or being
In the tenure or occupation of me such a one: ha?
Those are fine things indeed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why sir, you swore to me it was for love.

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: True; but there is two words to a bargain ever
All the world over, and if love be one
I am sure money is the other; it is no bargain else:
Pardon me, I must dine, as well as sup Widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Cry mercy, I mistook you all this while sir
It was this ancient Gentleman indeed,
Whom I crave pardon of .

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: What of me Widow?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Alas I have wronged you sir; it was you that swore
You loved me for myself !

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: By my troth but I did not
Come, Father not your lies upon me Widow:
I love you for yourself? spit at me Gentlemen
If ever I had such a thought, fetch me in Widow:
You will find your reach too short.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why you have enough you say.

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.p: Aye, but I will have my humour too; you never think of that, they are Coach horses, they go together still.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Whom should a Widow trust: I will swear it was one of you
That made me believe so : By'th'mass, think it was you sir
Now I remember me.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I swore too much
To be believed so little.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Was it you then?
Beshrew my heart for wronging of you.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Welcome blessing,
Are you mine faithfully now?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: As love can make one.

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: Why this fills the Commonwealth so full of beggars,
Marrying for love, which none of mine shall do .

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But now I think on it : we must part again sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Again ?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You are in debt, and I, in doubt of all,
Left myself nothing too; we must not hold,
Want on both sides makes all affection cold:
I shall not keep you from that Gentleman,
You will be his more than mine and when he list
He will make you lie from me in some sour prison,
Then let him take you now for altogether sir,
For he that is mine shall be all mine, or nothing.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I never felt the evil of my debts
Till this afflicting minute.

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.p: I will be mad once in my days: I have enough to cure me, and I will have my humour, they are now but desperate debts again . I never look for them ,
sp.l: And ever since I knew what malice was
I always held it sweeter to sow mischief.
Than to receive money; it is the finer pleasure.
I will give him in his bonds as it were in pity
To make the match, and bring them both to beggary,
Then will they never agree; that is a sure point,
He will give her a black eye within these three days,
Beat half her teeth out by Alhallontide,
And break the little household-stuff they have
With throwing at one another: O sweet sport.
Come Widow, come, I will try your honesty
Here to my honey you have, made many proffers,
I fear they are all but tricks: here are his debts Gentlemen:
How I came by them I know best myself .
Take him before us faithfully for your husband
And he shall tear them all before your face Widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Else may all faith refuse me:

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: Tear them honey
It is firm in Law, a consideration given:
What with thy teeth? thou wilt shortly tear her so
That is all my hope, thou hadst never had them else
I have enough, and I will have my humour.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I am now at liberty Widow.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I will be so too
And then I come to thee: give me this from you Brother.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Hold Sister: Sister.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Look you, the deed of gift sir, I am as free
He that has me, has all, and thou art he.
How is that ?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You are bobbed, it was but a deed in trust
And all to prove thee, whom I have found most just.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I am bobbed among the rest too: I would have sworn
It had been a thing for me, and my heirs forever;
If I had but got it up to the black box above
I had been past redemption

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: How am I cheated?

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: I hope you will have the conscience now to pay me sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: O wicked man, sower of strife and envy, open not thy lips.

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: How, how is this?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Thou hast no charge at all, no child of thine own
But two thou gottest once of a scouring woman,
And they are both well provided for , they are in the hospital,
Thou hast ten thousand pound to bury thee,
Hang thyself when thou wilt, a slave go with thee

sp.speaker: 2 Suter.
sp.l: I am gone, my goodness comes all out together.
I have enough, but I have not my humour.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: O Master, Gentlemen: and you sweet Widow
I think you are no forwarder yet, I know not,
If ever you be sure to laugh again ,
Now is the time.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why what is the matter wench?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Speak, speak.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Ha, a marriage, a marriage, I cannot tell it for laughing: ha, ha .

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: A marriage do you make that a laughing matter?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Ha: Aye, if you will make it so when you know all,
Here they come, here they come, one man married to another.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How? man to man?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Aye man to man in faith
There will be good sport at night to bring them both to bed;
Do you see them now, ha , ha , ha .

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: My daughter Martia.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: O my Father: your love, and pardon sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It is she indeed Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I have been disobedient I confess
Unto your mind, and Heaven has punished me
With much affliction since I fled your sight;
But finding reconcilement from above
In peace of heart; the next I hopes your love.

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: I cannot but forgive thee now I see thee,
Thou fleddest a happy fortune of an old man,
But Francisco is of a noble family,
Though he be somewhat spent.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I loved her not sir
As she was yours, for I protest I knew it not,
But for herself, sir, and her own deservings,
Which had you been as foul, as have been spiteful
I should have loved in her .

sp.speaker: 1 Suter.
sp.l: Well, hold your prating sir,
you are not like to loose by it .

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O Violetta, who shall laugh at us now?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: The child unborn Mistress.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Be good.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Be honest.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Heaven will not let you sin, and you would be careful.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: What means it sends to help you, think and mend,
You are as much bound as we , to praise that friend.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I am so , and I will so .

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Marry you speedily,
Children tame you, you will die like a wild beast else .

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I by my troth should I, I have much ado to forbear
Laughing now, more is my hard fortune.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O Master, Mistress, and you gentles all;
To horse, to horse presently, if you mean to do your Country any service.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Art not ashamed Martino, to talk of horsing so openly
Before young married couples thus.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It does concern the Commonwealth and me,
And you Master, and all: the Thieves are taken.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: What sayst Martino.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Law, here is Commonwealths men,
The man of art Master, that cupped your eyes
Is proved an arrant rascal: and his man
That drew my tooth, an excellent purse drawer,
I felt no pain in that , it went insensibly:
Such notable villainies confessed.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Stop there sir:
We will have time for them: Come gentlefolks,
Take a slight meal with us : but the best cheer
Is perfect joy, and that we wish all here. ~~
A sport only for Christmas, is the Play
This hour presents to you; to make you merry,
Is all the ambition it has ; and fullest aim
Bent at your smiles, to win itself, a name:
And if your edge be not quite taken off,
Wearied with sports, I hope it will make you laugh.
Stay stay Sir, I am as hungry of my Widow
As you can be upon your Maid believe it,
But we must come to our desires in order,
There is duties to be paid, ere we go further;
He that without your likings, leaves this place,
Is like one falls to meat, and forgets grace.
And that is not handsome trust me, no ,
Our rights being paid, and your loves understood,
My Widow, and my meat, then does me good;
I have no money Wench, I told thee true,
For my report, pray let her hear it from you.
